results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

In this film, titled ‘Our Garden’, Kenneth introduces us to the Rankine house (exterior) and garden as well as family and friends meeting and greeting the camera, playing ball games, showing off the family pet rabbit and dog and finally. This reel also introduces Bob Wootton who will marry daughter Bettye Rankine. Kenneth includes lingering shots of flowers which often feature throughout his films, often to separate his scenes. There are some great examples of the style and textiles of the clothes of the era and the family cars that feature in Kenneth’s reels. As proof that Bob Wootton is now in the family, Kenneth directs a kiss between him and his future mother-in-law to end the reel.

Selected highlights list:

00:04:12:00 women of the house posing in matching frocks and dodging bees where Kenneth has them pose.

00:04:27:00 the women eating watermelon.

00:04:54:00 one of the women wearing a uniform (possible of the WAAAF).

00:06:30:00 example of 1940 style dress with gloves and bag.
00:07:04:00 another uniform shot interspersed with flowers and the pet rabbit.

00:08:51:00 fruit trees are another feature of the garden and whilst collecting apricots, apples and green beans we see some examples of two piece sunsuits of the day.

00:14:11:00 title card ‘Peter’ begins a sequence featuring the family pet rabbit.

00:16:18:00 shows Mrs Rankine in a large black car in the driveway before shots of the lawns covered in hailstones or sleet.

00:16:31:00 title card ‘Kim’ introduces us to the family dog and to a young Bob Wootton who would become part of the family when married to Kenneth’s daughter.

00:17:30:00 title card ‘His First Bath’ shows the dog being washed in two enamel bowls typical of the time.

00:18:36:00 car being driven by Bob Wootton and members of the family in or near the car and playing with Kim.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was our first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This collection of silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 7 shows us more of the crowds and celebrations in central Melbourne.

Detailed Description Reel 7:

Opens with crowd scenes and aerial shots of motorcade along Spring Street end of Bourke Street, then arrival of motorcade at Victorian State Parliament. 00:00:38:00 marching band playing along street in front of crowds in roadside bleachers. 00:00:53:00 out-of-focus street parade scenes. 00:01:09:00 Queens Guard marching band. 00:01:19:00 mounted police. 00:01:54:00 Queens Guard marches up Swanston Street from Princes Bridge (and a press photographer gets caught by camera and hurries out of shot). 00:02:17:00 - 00:02:44:00 footage of the massive crowd in Swanston Street. Various crowd scenes in Melbourne CBD and at Government House. Ends with shots of motorcade on Swanston Street with Melbourne Town Hall in the background, and police holding back the crowd on the street.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows a family holiday along the east coast of Australia, beginning with the suspension bridge and dramatic cascades of water at the Hume Weir on the Victorian and New South Wales (NSW) border.

The family travels on to Timbertown near the town of Wauchope in NSW. Developed as a re-creation of an 1880-1910 working timber settlement, the tourist attraction ‘Timbertown’ was opened in the 1970s with some original buildings and some built to historic plans.

We also see a restored steam train, ‘The Green Hornet’ travel through bushland, a group of working bullocks and a glimpse of whip cracking. It’s then on to the Big Banana at Coffs Harbour, a Sikh Temple in NSW and some bushwalking.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:16:00 footbridge over the Hume Weir
00:00:30:00 close-up of the Hume Weir slipway followed by views around the Weir works
00:01:45:00 pelicans on the water
00:02:02:00 ‘Timbertown’ sign and a steam train with a great example of 1970s fashion ‘flares’ being worn in the foreground
00:02:15:00 children looking around ‘Timbertown’
00:02:25:00 a team of bullocks on a dusty road accompanied by a man carrying a large axe, followed by an old fashioned horse and cart
00:02:55:00 a demonstration of manual short plank splitting
00:03:25:00 children enjoy a ride through the trees on a steam train
00:03:50:00 whip cracking exhibition followed by ‘The Green Hornet’ in close up as it steams by
00:04:15:00 close up of the bullock yoke workings followed by a demonstration in a small arena of the bullocks team at work hauling a single large log
00:05:11:00 ‘The Big Banana’ and admirers at Coffs Harbour
00:05:40:00 sign for ‘The Vincent Tree’ after which the camera pans up a very tall tree trunk
00:06:54:00 botannical sign for ‘Yellow Carabeen Sloanea Woollisii’ and views of the tree
00:07:30:00 the family pose in the stocks of an old set of buildings which could be Middle Head Fort on the NSW coast
00:08:29:00 seabirds and various views of coastline and sea
00:09:13:00 the family on the beach
00:09:20:00 sign for the ‘Guru Nanak Sikh Temple’ rests on a brick wall, followed by the Temple
00:09:58:00 dramatic views of a ravinne and waterfall
00:10:30:00 children playing in an ‘Apex Park’ playground

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

In Reel 13 the royal couple visit towns in the Victorian region of Gippsland.

Detailed Description Reel 13:

Opens with Title “Visit to Gippsland Deplane at East Sale Aerodrome. Wednesday, 3rd. March, 1954”, followed by plane landing. 00:00:29:00 Queen and Duke exit plane. 00:01:07:00 motorcade through streets. 00:01:42:00 Queen and Duke exit car, mount dais, accompanied by local mayor. Queen makes speech. Locals are presented. 00:03:03:00 Queen and Duke re-enter car and motorcade drives through Sale streets. 00:04:15:00 footage switches to landscape and crowds outside moving train window. 00:04:29:00 Title “Traralgon”, followed by footage of the “Royal Train” pulling into station. 00:04:50:00 royal couple climb steps to dais. 00:05:12:00 crowd of Girl Guides in uniform, presentation of flowers to Queen on dais, crowd of Brownies in uniform (next to Girl Guides). 00:05:35:00 motorcade through Traralgon streets with Town Hall and Bank buildings just seen in background. 00:05:47:00 motorcade passes a Mobil oil station, with red 1950s bowsers outside. 00:06:25:00 footage from moving train, including an open cut coal mine. 00:06:40:00 Title “Yallourn”. No footage after 00:06:45:00 (film torn).

The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

In Reel 13 the royal couple visit towns in the Victorian region of Gippsland.

Detailed Description Reel 13:

Opens with Title “Visit to Gippsland Deplane at East Sale Aerodrome. Wednesday, 3rd. March, 1954”, followed by plane landing. 00:00:29:00 Queen and Duke exit plane. 00:01:07:00 motorcade through streets. 00:01:42:00 Queen and Duke exit car, mount dais, accompanied by local mayor. Queen makes speech. Locals are presented. 00:03:03:00 Queen and Duke re-enter car and motorcade drives through Sale streets. 00:04:15:00 footage switches to landscape and crowds outside moving train window. 00:04:29:00 Title “Traralgon”, followed by footage of the “Royal Train” pulling into station. 00:04:50:00 royal couple climb steps to dais. 00:05:12:00 crowd of Girl Guides in uniform, presentation of flowers to Queen on dais, crowd of Brownies in uniform (next to Girl Guides). 00:05:35:00 motorcade through Traralgon streets with Town Hall and Bank buildings just seen in background. 00:05:47:00 motorcade passes a Mobil oil station, with red 1950s bowsers outside. 00:06:25:00 footage from moving train, including an open cut coal mine. 00:06:40:00 Title “Yallourn”. No footage after 00:06:45:00 (film torn).

results.title: Fred's Films. [Luna Park] [excerpt]
results.brief_description: Filmed in the mid 1960s by steam train enthusiast and home movie maker Fred Daley who captures a family outing to the popular sea-side amusement park in St Kilda. ‘Luna Park’ is shown in all its summertime glory with the ‘River Boats’, the ‘Dodgems’, the ‘Rotor’ (a washing spin cycle for humans!), ‘The Spinner’ and of course its famous wooden roller coasters, the ‘Big Dipper’ and the ‘Scenic Railway’. Courageous Fred even films during the ride where you catch a glimpse of Port Phillip Bay from the very top!

results.title: [London, 1963 - 1964]
results.brief_description:
This silent, black-and-white footage of some of the major landmarks of London was shot in 1963–1964 by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett.

Opens with the Royal Marines Band playing, filmed as they march past the Duke of York Column and Waterloo Steps.

00:00:46:00 then Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, Alec Douglas-Home, farewelling a visitor on the steps of Number 10 Downing Street (the headquarters of British government).

00:01:11:00 camera pans down Nelson’s Column (a monument in Trafalgar Square, central London, commemorating Admiral Horatio Nelson.) We then see scenes of Trafalgar Square, with the National Gallery building and fountain both visible.

00:01:22:00 camera lingers on the equestrian statue of King Charles I, with the church of St Martin-in-the-Fields in the background.

00:01:28:00 London traffic, with the camera focussing especially on cabs (taxis).

00:01:43:00 the Admiralty Arch.

00:01:49:00 double-decker London bus in front of some classic 1960’s style adverstising signs in Piccadilly Circus, with the Eros statue visible.

00:02:04:00 Eros statue in close-up.

00:02:22:00 Underground (railway) sign in close-up, followed by scenes in the Underground itself; ticket queues, escalators, and a train coming into a platform.

00:02:46:00 “Piccadilly Circus” station sign visible on the wall of the train tunnel

The film ends with footage of the tunnel, shot from the moving train.

results.title: [Construction of the Water Tower at Fletcher Jones Factory, Warrnambool, 1967]
results.brief_description:
The Fletcher Jones factory and Gardens at 61–81 Flaxman Street, Warrnambool (established 1948) are famous local landmarks and symbolic of the radical approach to industrial relations and the provision of workplace amenities taken by the famous Australian company. The complex, including the Water Tower, was listed on the Victorian Heritage Register in 2006 in recognition of its historic and social significance which notes “…the unusual and successful integration of surplus military structures, buildings and modernist facade in a factory setting. They reflect the resourcefulness and dynamism of Fletcher Jones in the use of war surplus structures and objects during a time of building material shortages.”

The forty-metre-high water tower – built for fire protection and as a booster system – was designed and supervised by Ralph Jones Construction Engineering Services between 1965–1967. [Source: University of Melbourne Archives: Ralph Jones Water Tower Submission and Business Papers].

This silent, black-and-white footage of the tower’s construction was photographed by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett. It is a unique historic documentary record of the construction of an iconic feature of Warrnambool’s – and Victoria’s – industrial heritage.

results.title: Patsy Comes To Stay
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is a silent comedy narrative entitled ‘Patsy Comes to Stay’, which was produced by the Victorian Amateur Cine Society. The film was directed by H.J.D. Law and features Rankine as the Chief of Police.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 27]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is the second of two that capture a family holiday to far north Queensland and the Great Barrier Reef in May, 1975.

The Gadsden family travel by yacht to visit a tropical shore, enjoy an evening barbeque, go scuba diving and bask in the sun. They then travel to the town of Kuranda by train going through some spectacular rainforest scenery on their way.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:22:00 passenger yacht ‘Tiki’ anchors off an island and lets down a rowboat.
00:00:40:00 wallabies and kangaroos join the travellers for lunch
00:00:59:00 a kangaroo eating bread from its paws
00:01:31:00 old coral and shells on a beach
00:02:00:00 various efforts to break open a coconut
00:03:07:00 eating the coconut
00:03:20:00 tropical flowers, banana trees, palms and views around the landscape
00:04:12:00 lunch being set up on the beach – cutting vegetables and a makeshift barbeque plate on the sand
00:04:23:00 entering the water for snorkelling
00:04:49:00 sausages and onion rings on the barbeque plate with flames underneath
00:05:34:00 serving food from the barbeque to the travellers
00:05:57:00 the travellers picnic on the beach
00:06:18:00 sunbathing on the beach
00:07:00:00 speeding across the water
00:07:05:00 pamphlet for ‘Cairns-Kuranda’ rail trip showing the route the travellers will follow.
00:07:25:00 lovely old train
00:07:45:00 passengers boarding a train at a rail station
00:07:54:00 views from the moving train - the track below, sugar cultivation and lush hills
00:08:23:00 ‘Redlynch’ rail station with glimpses of pot plants and ferns typical of Queensland
00:09:05:00 scenic views and waving children
00:09:25:00 view of the train snaking ahead
00:10:00:00 views of the lush landscape from a higher vantage point
00:10:25:00 the train travels through tunnels and close vegetation and local onlookers standing by the tracks
00:10:36:00 train travels over a lovely old wooden bridge as it rises higher into the forest covered hills
00:10:58:00 a waterfall
00:11:30:00 looking out over fields to the sea as the train keeps moving along
00:11:44:00 train travels past labourers – probably from sugar cane fields
00:12:00:00 a sign for ‘Barron Falls’
00:12:29:00 the camera inadvertently captures a fashion moment from the 1970s – long hair in low ‘pigtails’ tied with equally long green narrow ribbons
00:12:44:00 the Gadsden travellers looking out the train window
00:12:54:00 Jess Gadsden among other sightseers hopping back onto the train from a lookout point
00:13:20:00 coming into the picturesque Kuranda rail station filled with pot plants and foliage and views around the station
00:14:16:00 sign for ‘Kuranda’
00:14:33:00 the Gadsden travellers enjoy a beer whilst at Kuranda Station

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 167]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is a wonderful composite of several different sequences in different periods of time, including the 1934 floods in Melbourne, tennis and gardens in the 1930s, beach scenes in the 1950s and the 1956 Melbourne Olympics.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 very dramatic flooding around Melbourne, which is likely to be 1934 when major flooding from torrential rains affected large areas of the city.
00:00:02:00 people looking out over a flooded road and possibly submerged bridge toward urban buildings on the the hillsides on the other side of the floodwaters. We may assume a trip to town has been stopped by the floods as the group are dressed for an outing. This could be Yarra river at some point.
00:00:55:00 several cars (1930s and 1940s models) in a city street with tram tracks, stuck at a flooded dip in the road; the scene includes a brief look at a motor bike. This could be Bourke Road, Camberwell as the area was flooded during the 1934 floods, the road is hilly and has tram tracks.
00:00:57:00 more flooded streets and a sign for ‘Glendebourne Ave’ which places the footage in Toorak.
00:01:33:00 a tremendously flooded Yarra River in the Melbourne CBD with onlookers observing the rushing waters lapping up over the bank, and a view toward Princes Bridge. Includes a man casually walking along completely indifferent to the flood.
00:02:05:00 we again see the fast running flooded river which could be around Yarra Bend Park as there are canoes on the bank, a traditional boating spot.
00:02:31:00 footage changes abruptly to colour and a 1950s beach scene with four people wandering along the sand; the two mean are dressed for swimming, the two women more formally. They sit and chat on the sand while the women have a cigarette.
00:02:55:00 surfing in the waves on a beach; some of the the surfboards appear to be the early wooden type of board.
00:03:15:00 two women in a garden and then footage of one of them very happy to be trying out a bicycle.
00:04:28:00 black and white scenes of a garden including some children at a table and chairs setting taken with the camera overhead from a top floor.
00:05:05:00 scenes of a river, probably the Yarra near one of the family homes in Kew or Hawthorn. We see children and then a woman swinging out on a knotted rope swing; the style of dresser and swimming costumes indicate the 1930s or 1940s.
00:05:52:00 outside views of a house, possibly a Gadsden home. The style of house and hedged fence would be found in either Kew or Hawthorn.
00:05:58:00 children participating in a swimming competition at a pool.
00:06:00:00 tennis being played in garden we saw earlier; likely to be one of the Gadsden homes during the 1930s or 1940s.
00:08:03:00 members of the family swimming and practising diving in a large public pool.
00:10:39:00 more views around a large ivy-covered house and the gardens, likely to be a Gadsden home.
00:11:22:00 picnic on a beach that included lots of flies (by the look of all the shooing) and Ronald and Jess Gadsden, both at a young age and a woman eating a sandwich in a car.
00:11:54:00 a small girl smiling at the camera while eating her share of a picnic and then playing with a ball and stick.
00:12:22:00 older members of the family seeing off Ronald and his wife Jess in their car.
00:13:08:00 colour scenes of Jess Gadsden picking flowers and wearing a ‘sunsuit’ typical of the 1940s or 1950s era. We also see Ronald Gadsden tending soil in the garden with a small (cutlery) fork.
00:13:39:00 several shots of Ronald tossing a shotput in what appears to be a competition or practice for a competition.
00:14:02:00 Ronald and others climbing a lookout quickly followed by Jess looking very confident happy on horseback and then Ronald riding a horse as well. This could be at their farm at Lancefield in regional Victoria.
00:14:41:00 family tennis court, filmed in colour (same court as earlier in black and white) where we see Jess and Ronald play with other family members.
00:16:31:00 the camera is back at the beach, in colour with Ronald a little older dabbling his toe in the water for the camera.
00:17:18:00 scenes in black and white showing Jess and Ronald’s son Geoffrey, riding on a miniature train in a park.
00:18:05:00 Gadsden children in black and white sequence, playing under the garden hose.
00:18:34:00 Ronald and son are riding an elephant presumably at the zoo and then son Geoffrey playing on playground equipment.
00:19:32:00 steam trains and ‘red rattler’ commuter trains with young Geoffrey looking on from a walkbridge.
00:20:50:00 night time scenes of the city’s neon signs in order to capture the decorations installed for the royal visit in 1954.
00:21:47:00 motorcade for the visiting royals.
00:24:18:00 crowds watching the royal motorcade and in particular a quick clear shot of the Queen in an open car. Of note also is the number of ladders and kitchen stools brought along by members often crowd to gain vantage points.
00:24:22:00 opening of the Olympic Games in Melbourne 1956, including Ron Clarke running along the stadium track with the Torch as well as the assembled countries and flags and the Olympic flag.
00:28:40:00 snow slopes and skiers appear and we see a series of shots including Jess Gadsden and some older women of the family walking and posing in front of what could be their holiday house.
00:31:00:00 an interior shot of what might be a country holiday house near the snow or a chalet with family members chatting.
00:31:13:00 an older member of the family playing with young children on the family tennis court which is now unmarked.
00:33:35:00 members of the extended family gather with all of their children for a family occasion. At one point, the children all parade past the camera in single file.
